trans-unit.source: Using the Docker VM Extension for Linux on Azure
trans-unit.target: Using the Docker VM Extension for Linux on Azure

trans-unit.source: Describes Docker and the Azure Virtual Machines extensions, and shows how to programmatically create Virtual Machines on Azure that are docker hosts from the command line using the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: Describes Docker and the Azure Virtual Machines extensions, and shows how to programmatically create Virtual Machines on Azure that are docker hosts from the command line using the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: Using the Docker VM Extension with the Azure Portal
trans-unit.target: Using the Docker VM Extension with the Azure Portal

trans-unit.source: [Docker](https://www.docker.com/) is one of the most popular virtualization approaches that uses [Linux containers](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LXC) rather than virtual machines as a way of isolating data and computing on shared resources.
trans-unit.target: [Docker](https://www.docker.com/) is one of the most popular virtualization approaches that uses [Linux containers](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LXC) rather than virtual machines as a way of isolating data and computing on shared resources.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Docker VM extension managed by [Azure Linux Agent] to create a Docker VM that hosts any number of containers for your applications on Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Docker VM extension managed by [Azure Linux Agent] to create a Docker VM that hosts any number of containers for your applications on Azure.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This topic describes how to create a Docker VM from the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This topic describes how to create a Docker VM from the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: To see how to create a Docker VM at the command line, see [How to use the Docker VM Extension from the Azure Command-line Interface (Azure CLI)].
trans-unit.target: To see how to create a Docker VM at the command line, see [How to use the Docker VM Extension from the Azure Command-line Interface (Azure CLI)].

trans-unit.source: To see a high-level discussion of containers and their advantages, see the [Docker High Level Whiteboard](http://channel9.msdn.com/Blogs/Regular-IT-Guy/Docker-High-Level-Whiteboard).
trans-unit.target: To see a high-level discussion of containers and their advantages, see the [Docker High Level Whiteboard](http://channel9.msdn.com/Blogs/Regular-IT-Guy/Docker-High-Level-Whiteboard).

trans-unit.source: Create a new VM from the Image Gallery
trans-unit.target: Create a new VM from the Image Gallery

trans-unit.source: The first step requires an Azure VM from a Linux image that supports the Docker VM Extension, using an Ubuntu 14.04 LTS image from the Image Gallery as an example server image and Ubuntu 14.04 Desktop as a client.
trans-unit.target: The first step requires an Azure VM from a Linux image that supports the Docker VM Extension, using an Ubuntu 14.04 LTS image from the Image Gallery as an example server image and Ubuntu 14.04 Desktop as a client.

trans-unit.source: In the portal, click **+ New** in the bottom left corner to create a new VM instance and select an Ubuntu 14.04 LTS image from the selections available or from the complete Image Gallery, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: In the portal, click **+ New** in the bottom left corner to create a new VM instance and select an Ubuntu 14.04 LTS image from the selections available or from the complete Image Gallery, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Currently, only Ubuntu 14.04 LTS images more recent than July 2014 support the Docker VM Extension.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Currently, only Ubuntu 14.04 LTS images more recent than July 2014 support the Docker VM Extension.

trans-unit.target: Create Docker Certificates

trans-unit.source: After the VM has been created, ensure that Docker is installed on your client computer.
trans-unit.target: After the VM has been created, ensure that Docker is installed on your client computer.

trans-unit.source: (For details, see [Docker installation instructions](https://docs.docker.com/installation/#installation).)
trans-unit.target: (For details, see [Docker installation instructions](https://docs.docker.com/installation/#installation).)

trans-unit.source: Create the certificate and key files for Docker communication according to [Running Docker with https] and place them in the **`~/.docker`** directory on your client computer.
trans-unit.target: Create the certificate and key files for Docker communication according to [Running Docker with https] and place them in the **`~/.docker`** directory on your client computer.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The Docker VM Extension in the portal currently requires credentials that are base64 encoded.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The Docker VM Extension in the portal currently requires credentials that are base64 encoded.

trans-unit.source: At the command line, use **`base64`** or another favorite encoding tool to create base64-encoded topics.
trans-unit.target: At the command line, use **`base64`** or another favorite encoding tool to create base64-encoded topics.

trans-unit.target: Add the Docker VM Extension

trans-unit.source: To add the Docker VM Extension, locate the VM instance you created and scroll down to **Extensions** and click it to bring up VM Extensions, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: To add the Docker VM Extension, locate the VM instance you created and scroll down to **Extensions** and click it to bring up VM Extensions, as shown below.

trans-unit.target: Add an Extension

trans-unit.source: Add the Docker Communication Endpoint
trans-unit.target: Add the Docker Communication Endpoint

trans-unit.source: When viewing your VM in the resource group you've created, scroll down to click **Endpoints** to view the endpoints on the VM as shown here.
trans-unit.target: When viewing your VM in the resource group you've created, scroll down to click **Endpoints** to view the endpoints on the VM as shown here.
